intro: Arabis caduca, commonly known as the annual rockcress, is a flowering plant native to temperate regions of Europe and Asia. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, which includes many economically important crops. The plant typically grows to a height of 10–30 cm and produces small, white or pale yellow flowers in clusters. Its leaves are basal, rosette-like, and covered in fine hairs, while the stems are usually hairless. Arabis caduca is often found in disturbed soils and rocky areas, thriving in full sun.
